segments.text: Okay, now was Colonel Patton in charge at this time?
Colonel Patton was more or less a second-in-command of the 2nd Armored Division as a colonel and he promoted the brigadier and then to division commander.
And he remained as division commander until we started for Africa
We landed in Africa on November the 8th, 1942.
Just prior to that time, I had been assigned, I had been pulled out of the 2nd Army Division temporarily and assigned to
the 5th Army Division out in California to do some, make some determinations in the desert on whether or not we have gasoline engines or diesel engines.
The schooling was the forerunner of that.
So, I ran these tests out in the desert.
As soon as that was over,
six months, I guess, or so.
I was sent on a very sensitive mission to South America by another agency of our government.
And when I finished that- Well, can you tell me about that?
A member of the Navy and I from the Army had been selected.
Best I can say to you is that German submarines were putting people ashore in Brazil.
Agents ashore.
And I was sent to Belém, Brazil.
there in activities which I don't want to discuss.
This is in 1942?
No, this was in 1942.
And then I went- Then did you miss Operation Torch or did you go through with the landing in North Africa?
I missed it by a few days, joined them just about the time it was over with.
Well, why did they pick you to take on the sensitive mission to Brazil?

I think that determination was made by my regimental and division commander at the time, which they had been placed a requirement to send a guy of a certain caliber and mentality and experience and that sort of thing.
So that's what happened.
And how long did this last?
It lasted until December of about the first of December 1942 and I went straight away back to the Second Army Division.
So it was an OSS operation basically?
Sort of thing, yes.
Except
another branch of the federal government had a responsibility.

And the reason I don't want to touch on that too much is a simple reason that there is still conflict within our government as to who has responsibilities on certain security matters outside the United States.
There's a lot of controversy.
And I don't want to get involved in participating in that.
I just know that we didn't have a CIA back in the old days, but we did have a FBI, right?
And a damn good one under one of the greatest guys that ever lived, J. Edgar Hoover.
And I don't see his picture here, but it's in this household somewhere.
He was one hell of a man.
I don't give a damn what people say about him now.
I think he's one of the greatest guys that we've ever had.
So you had an opportunity to meet him?
Oh, I know him, yes.
Well, now that we're on him, can you describe your meeting with him?
Well, he was a man of uncommon loyalty and honesty to the United States of America.
Uncommon in that regard.
Ruthless on inefficiencies and any incompetencies that might occur, and I believe in all those things.
I am very ruthless, and I've become very controversial in the military about that sort of thing.
Amongst seniors who should be very confident or shouldn't be there.
I felt this very strongly about him.
I thought he was a nice warm man and I liked him very much.
Warm usually isn't the word that most people use with Jagger.
No, but he had a personal feeling.
He treated me that way, I tell you.
And did you get to meet him then in 1942 or was this later on?
Later on, later on.
Later on.
And in what capacity?
I've been a very strong law enforcement type guy.
You can see a few badges up there.
I think that

that the military has a responsibility for not only exterior but interior security, but I would like to thank the people that's got the greatest responsibility for interior security as our national state
and county police systems for internal security.
For external security, the Army, Navy, and Air Force, and Marines, and the Coast Guard.
But in order, if the internal security, the interior, had a problem that it can't cope with,
The Army, Navy, Air Force, Coast Guard, Marines are there to assist.

So, if you're doing your job in the military, and particularly in the Army, you've got to know as much about the internal security makeup and systems and how it performs and works and its inadequacies and its advantages and disadvantages and
and that sort of thing in order for you to properly support it and work with it.
And as a result of that, I gained their respect and confidence wherever I signed in the United States.
And I've been involved in many seminars with law enforcement agencies.
We're in the FBI and the alcohol, tobacco,
people, the county sheriffs, the municipal chief of police, state security elements, state highway patrol, and so on and forth involved in.
I've lectured in their schools continuously ever go, worked with them.
and offered advice and assistance and gained their support and the management of my own 30 or 40,000 man fort and the people that's involved and that sort of stuff, you see.
So, that's how it came about.
Well, tell me about Patton.
Well, I like to say this, that
First off, I can't be a Patton.
Nobody can be a Patton.
Nobody can be me.
Nobody can be you.
And some people say, oh, he's trying to be another Patton.
Anybody's foolish and unknowingly foolish if they say that about anybody.
But I like...
the way he operated.
I liked the way he could ride a horse.
I liked the way he could shoot a shotgun.
I liked the way he could run a yacht.
I liked the way he was really a proud historian.
That's what made George Patton his history.
George, he graduated.
He took a five-year course at West Point like I did at A&M, except I didn't have to go the fifth year.
I just had to wait out my diploma.
He took five years at West Point to get through.
But history made George the love of history, just like that's what's going to do for you.
You see?
Why do you want to go out and make the same mistake next year that was made 35 years ago?
Well, the reason you do it is you didn't know it was made 35 years ago or you wouldn't make it, would you?
Huh?
Well, how in the hell did you find out what happened 35 years ago?
By God, you've got to study history.
Now, sometimes you're going to find that it was recorded very poorly and it's very difficult to interpret, and there's an art of recording.
so people can interpret, you know, a recording history.

The main thing I guess about that is the fact that you've got to, and I found this true in the military, that to record everything that occurred in this particular battle that's been going on for the last five days, at the conclusion of it, is a very wasteful thing to history.

because there's no way you can remember every detail it should have been recorded every day at the end of the day but who is it that can go five days and five nights and close in the rural pocket and I did that on the north and record everything sometime during the night
When you're so dead tired and you're so worried about your troops and worried about getting your objective, who in the hell is going to spend the time on writing what happened that day?
And who can afford a historian when you're running your tank cruiser short?
History, we lose so much of history.
It's so invaluable.
And then somebody tries to go back and make it up, and then we accept that as a fact when it wasn't a fact.
I'll tell you what I'm saying to you has cost us a great president, Dick Nixon.
In my view, he was trying to record history as it really was.
and not what somebody writes about it four years ago when he forgot about what had happened and he filled in.
What contribution does that make?
In other words, the use of the taping system?
Absolutely.
Let's get back to Patton here now.
When did you first meet George Patton?
I met George Patton in July 1940 at Fort Benning, Georgia.
July 14th.
I met him at the division headquarters.
Oh, your first impressions?
My first impression was that, god damn, that guy really is a sharp looking officer.
And I saw a distinguished service cross.
That's next to the Congressional Medal of Honor.
Now, you can get the Congressional Medal of Honor.
Occasionally, you'll find a guy that lives, but most of the time they're posthumously.
So, a distinguished service cross is a very
sort of thing for Extraordinary Heroes, and I liked that.
And he had a silver star.
I know what that is, too.
And a very interesting thing that he interviewed me and thanked me for coming in and said, we're going to learn to fight this division, new division, new farm division.
We're going to learn to fight it.
We're going to learn to do it together and I expect you to meet all the standards and all that.
I said, yes, sir, and I saluted.
When I got to my unit that I was assigned to, that's when I found out that
You're going to be in this battalion, Major Fry said to me, and on field exercise you're going to work with Colonel Patton.
He'd already called him up and told him, you see.
Why do you think he picked you?
I don't know.
Maybe he liked the way I looked, the way I wore my uniform or something.
Maybe he liked the way I talked.
You know, you can talk to, you can look at a guy, just like I told you,
a little earlier about yourself.
See, I didn't have to talk to you about a couple of minutes and look at you.
You see what I mean?
If you've been involved in this business of leadership, see?
Oh, yes, it doesn't take many.
I didn't know that then.
What kind of leader?
A lot of controversy is around Pat and his form of leadership.
What did you think of his form?
Let me give you an example.
He had put out a message to all the regiments that he did not want to see any more tanks
being driven around in training exercises with the hatches open.
He said, I want all the hatches down and locked and learn to live that way because you're training for battle.
That makes sense, doesn't it?

So I had all of the tanks of the whole battalion, me being the only second lieutenant and being the training officer and not knowing anything, the only one thing else, and company commander, first lieutenant, had other things to do.
And so I would take all the tanks out in the field every day for training.
300 tanks?
No, no, 56 tanks for the battalion.
300 was in the regiment, and now in a division.
I mean in the division, 300 in the division.
Back in those days we had 56 per battalion and three battalions so you'd see 162.
But anyway, I was out in the training area and we'd been out there all day and we'd
carried along a sack lunch, and we were supposed to get back in and do maintenance on all these vehicles, and then we had some classwork that we had to go to, classes on subjects.
So, at a place called Turkey Ford, the water run down through this creek, and we called that a ford there, Turkey Ford,
famous area there and the old reservation at Fort Benning.
The memorandum that he had published had been sent out, but it had not reached the battalion level, or at least the distribution hadn't gotten down to the companies yet.
He had put the message out, and he's out now checking to see if it's being complied with and why it wasn't being complied with if it wasn't.
In other words, this is a principle.
You put something out, now go check to see that it's been done.
That's what he was doing.
Well, I crossed Turkey Ford.
I was leading the tank back in.
And I had the turrets open because this is a small dirt road.
And I thought, well, I should have these turrets open so I'd call the fellas on the radio, give them signals.
We had flags for signals which open your turrets because otherwise, so we can, we'd been driving with them closed out on the range, out in the woods.
So you were no longer in the battle area?
We were no longer in the battle area.
We were leaving.
And were they closed when you were in the battle area?
Yes, they were closed in the battle area, but this was just a road through the woods coming back.
Going back to the base.
Going back to where I went into Cassetta Road, which is a blacktop road.
And I knew I had to have them open then.
That had been specifically brought out without anybody for safety reasons.
Well, we were on his road.
His staff car, I noticed his staff car parked back off in the woods.
We come down through Turkey Ford water, come up on the tank on the front, and we come out of there.
And, man, he walked out on the road and held it with his hand and stopped.
So I pushed him back in the old days.
You just touch the driver in the back between the shoulders with your foot there.
That's the way he stopped them, so he stopped.
I jumped out of the tank, went over and slew them.
He said, Lieutenant, don't you ever read these memorandums?
I said, yes, sir.
He said, well, then why in the hell aren't you complying with it?
He said, now, if you read these memorandums, you'll know that you're supposed to have these turrets closed in your battle area.
You're training for battle.
By God, you get them closed up right now.
Yes, sir.
I had seen them around.
Did you tell them that?
No.
Why not?
Oh, no.
That was the way it was in those days.
Yes, sir.
No, sir.
Well, we got on out Cassetta Road.
I knew the safety factor was such that you got to open them up.
We get on Cassetta Road.
We're going about two miles, and we come to Mike.

regimental headquarters which is in tents across from a place called Harmony Church and we had to go by there about a mile in turn to get in our bivouac area where we were living in tents and as we approached the regimental headquarters his staff car was there and he started to pull out
hit the siren button on the tank and the siren went off and here he jumps out, Patton jumps out of his car again, this is the second time today, and stopped my tank column.
This time I was getting a little shook up about this business, frightened really, because
I thought for a second lieutenant to be called on the mat twice a day is a little bit too much.
And I was feeling unkindly toward the driver who automatically hit the siren.
And so I jumped out of the tank.
What was the siren so the staff car would not come out on the road?
Yeah, that's exactly what the driver was doing.
He gave him a warning.
Yeah, exactly.
And why wasn't that not a good idea?
It was, but I was shook up about it.
No, let me finish with this.
I get out and I report to him.
He said, Lieutenant, why did you blow that siren?
I didn't say, I didn't, sir.
The driver did.
I said,
Sir, the driver blew that siren because he wanted to warn you that we were coming through, and he didn't want to hit your vehicle.
He said, Lieutenant, that is a way to use your head.
That is a damn fine action on your whole crew's part, and thank you very much, and good luck to you.
I can't put this what I thought then on here, but I said, oh, God.
He visited me many times, and I worked with him, and I just thought he was great.
Here one time he was admonishing me for not doing what I didn't, you know, I didn't know what I was doing, but I accepted that.
And then the second time, a little soldier does something that's,
you're unconscious of him doing and you and the little soldier all get complimented on what the little soldier did.
And I've been complimented so many times on what the soldier did that I didn't do.
And that makes you a very humble man and very respectful of the heart and mind and the soul of others.
So Georgie was a human being like the rest of us.

Regardless of how much experience you had or how old you are, if you're going to do something, if you're going to do anything at all, if you're going to make a contribution in life, you're going to make mistakes.
And I don't care if you're 90 years old or you're six months old.
That's just exactly the way it is.
That's a principle.
That's a known part of the art of life.
Now, if you do something, you're going to make a contribution, one way or the other.
Either it's going to be good or it's going to be bad.
I think it was Napoleon, a Chinese philosopher, I can't remember his name, told me one time,
He learned more from making mistakes than he did from doing things right.
Now, of course, Patton came into a lot of controversy later on in his career when he was in the hospital in Sicily and slapped that young man and also when he was driving into Germany and
and many of the other generals of Eisenhower's staff thought that he was trying to grab all the glory at their expense.
And of course, he had a feud with Field Marshal Montgomery, too.
Were you involved, or do you have opinions of any of those episodes?
Well, I was in Sicily during the slapping incidents, and I was in Normandy before Georgie was for the Third Army.

you know you gather information if you're interested from those that you see that were present and hearsay from others and when it's hearsay you always question whether it's right or wrong unless you got the art of

Cornelius Ryan, and I spent four years on a book and researched back and forth everything that there is, and you don't, you're not writing a book on what's happening, you're trying to just, for your own interest, find out what's happened, so you do get a fair feel, I think, of generally what's happening.
What did you, what about the slapping incident here in Sicily?
What was the feeling among the officers and the troops?
Nobody paid any attention to that sort of thing.
This is all a press explosion.
Press explosion.
Nobody pays any attention to it.
You see, one of the principles that you have in the military is that the officer never lays a hand on an enlisted man.
I can't tell you the million

times that I walked up and put my arm around a little soldier that had done a hell of a good job and then pinned a medal on him or just walked up and shook hands with him and talked to him when he's the most lonesome guy in the whole battlefield and I know what it does to him and I violated all rules never lay a hand on a soldier
and they just love it.
I don't condone striking anybody in the military and civilian life.
What the hell's to be gained from that?
It's a compulsion.
It's a driving sense of respect for others in the case of Georgie Patton that he sensed a guy.
that was trying to shirk his duties when soldiers out there were being killed and maimed and lying in the hospital dying.
And here's a whimpering guy sitting over there, by his very nature, may or may not have been able to control
his fears.
And Georgie instantaneously, not, with a dead sense of dedication to those that are dead out there, slapped this guy with his gloves.
Well, isn't that bad?
Yeah, I guess it is.
Is it worthy of being exploding in the newspaper and so on and forth?
No.
Was it worthy of the condemnation of Georgia Patton by Eisenhower and so on and forth?
Eisenhower being a political general, in his mind, obviously yes, if you're a politician, if you're a political general.
You see, Mr. Eisenhower ducked World War II.
He'd never heard a shot fired in anger.
Georgie won the distinguished service cross with a shot up leg on the front end of a
an old tank in World War I.
So you got different characters there.
Bradley, he'd had a little or no combat experience during World War II.
And same with the rest of them.
They were in three and four star positions.
Georgie had.
Georgie was a combat leader.
And that's quite different from the staff types.
And all that you had sitting at the top during World War II were the staff types.
Except Georgie and maybe one or maybe two others.
And I can't think of who the others might be right at the moment.
He has received criticism that he pushed his men too hard.
What about that?
Soldiers, American, red-blooded American soldiers, you can't push them too hard because they like the challenge.
They like the adventure and like the challenge, and they were born with it, and by God, they want it there, and you can't give them too much to do.
I always looked at it this way.
Don't expect them to go beyond their capability, and you've got to make a judgment on their capability.
It's like closing off the Aurora Pocket in January, I guess it was, of 1945.
We went five days and five nights without any sleep.
Nobody complained about that.

sure tank crews would go to sleep or you'd stop if they weren't in action and all the actions up front and they'd get ready to move somebody had to go those that weren't totally involved in the battle you had to go wake them up well you'd say what are you doing right there no you don't do that say look get going here damn it stay up let's get up go get going um
Well, did I push them too hard or did the division commander push me too hard?
That doesn't ever enter anybody's mind.
That never really enters anybody's mind.
I don't think you can be pushed too hard.
There's an inspiring thing about battle to succeed and you always look to the leader because he's the oldest

you would you hope with the most judgment and most wisdom and uh you know when you're 25 years old and you command 3,000 people I guess I was the oldest uh as little judgment and wisdom as I had I guess I was the oldest everybody looked I know my sergeant major was 19
with one year out of University of Tennessee and his name is Rip Thornton.
He's CPA now.
And he is absolutely phenomenal because my sergeant major got killed on the beach in Normandy who had about 15 years service.
What a heck of a guy.
I had no one.
You don't get replacements for those people.
So I just took my
clerk who had what we called T-4 back in those days.
He'd be a buck sergeant now, 19 years old.
You're the sergeant major.
If you haven't learned from him, the dead one, I said, you and I will make a few mistakes together.
He said, Roger that, sir.
So we went on with it.
Now let's go back to North Africa.
Tell me about your campaign now.
North Africa was a disaster.
The whole campaign in North Africa started out as kind of after the landing.
After the Second Armored Division and the Ninth Infantry Division landed down at Puerto Leote and Safi and took Casablanca, they went to Cork Forest and retrained there.
We fought the French for three days.
The French finally gave up.
And then— Actually, you were in combat with the French?
With the French, yeah.
You fought the hell out of them, yeah.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
Three days.
Mm-hmm.
So they get capitulated on the 11th of November.
You got to understand, I was not there.
I was down in another census or something.
But I got there immediately after that and went back to my regiment in 67.
was the 68th.
When it started out, we reorganized and we ended up with two regiments.
We just had a 66th and a 67th regiment because the 68th was a light tank regiment and we split it up amongst the other two medium regiments.
Because we just had so damn many tanks, you couldn't handle them all in the division.
So how many were you in charge of?
I was in charge of, at the end of the war.
No, right at the beginning.
Okay.
Seventeen.
Three platoons of five inch in each and two in the headquarters.
Okay.
And you usually rode in the first one?
Rode in the first tank.
Yeah, company commander tank.
Okay.
And then you uh—after the— Where was the first action that you saw?
Up in Tunisia.
The background on that is—
The 1st Armored Division and the 1st Infantry Division had landed at Oran, Algiers.
Simultaneously with the 2nd Armored and the 9th Infantry landing down at Casablanca and taking Casablanca.
The High Command was worried about
We were in French Morocco and we had the other Morocco there, Spanish Morocco.
We didn't know which way the Spanish were going to go and they'd been playing footsie with the Germans.
A lot of Germans down there in Spanish Morocco and we thought that they were going to try
pull some kind of leg up and sabotage the deal to bust our supply lines against Rommel's forces over there in the 8th Army, British 8th Army.
Meantime, the 1st Infantry and the 1st Armored go through Algiers into Tunisia, and they're up at Kasserine Pass in the general area.
Had a corps commander named General Friedenthal
His performance along with the 1st Armored Division commander's performance was not to the high command's liking and wasn't acceptable to anybody, so they both were relieved.
Meantime, Georgie, they had a hell of a lot of losses, tank losses.
Georgie still commanded the Western Task Force, which was the second arm of the 9th Army Division.
General Ernie Harmon had the second Army Division at the time.
Georgie was selected to go take that second corps under Kasserine Pies.

And doing so, he took tank units and officers with him, kind of borrowed them out of the 2nd Armored Division to go up there to reestablish until they could get replacements, get tanks, and that sort of stuff, because he had to get on it.
And that's how I got involved up there.
And so you were one of the ones that he took.
And then I ended up at Berzerdi.
at the end of the war.
The rest of the Second Armored Division was preparing for Sicilian operation.
But that's where you met Rommel, up at the Kasserine Pass?
No, I fought some of his units.
I had met him.
Yeah, that's where I went.
You fought some of his units?
Yeah.
Now would you comment on the quality of Rommel's tank commanders?
I guess they're the best soldiers that I've ever fought against.
They're not as tenacious as the Communists.
I don't know what the Communists do to their soldiers, but the tenacity of them is pretty damn effective, pretty strong.
A German soldier, he had a warrior.
like American.
When he's totally surrounded, he doesn't fight the last man and that sort of crap.
I haven't seen many American units do that either.
There's no hatred, I don't believe, among soldiers.
In other words, your men didn't hate the Germans that much?
They sort of respected them as soldiers?
Yeah, you've got to respect them or they're going to kick hell out of you.
You know what I'm talking about?
You've got to respect their capabilities.
And by God, they better respect yours, too, or he'll get his damn clock cleaned.
So that's the way it is amongst warriors, you know.
No question about it.
Hell, you know, you don't hate the enemy as a person.
Much dislike as I have for communism, those soldiers out there are people, you know.
And he's out there under orders to kill you or to do this, that, and the other.
And hopefully someday our country will get back to the fact that it won't be a sin to kill an enemy soldier when you're in battle instead of trying to love him to death.
That happens in any country wherein politicians get involved in telling generals how in the hell to fight the battle and what targets he ought to hit and that sort of stuff.
When you get into that, you can be criticized for saying to the press that you're going to kill the enemy before he gets back in Cambodia.
And you can get criticized to beat hell like I did.
Well, I was out to destroy the enemy, and I had to keep them from killing my soldiers.
Yeah, well, we're going to get to that.
So, tell me about your first contact in battle.
Well, I guess you're very frightened, but if you've learned to do everything right during your training, it helps you to overcome your fear as you gain confidence.
a tremendous amount of confidence by being successful.
That's the truth.
What was the situation at the Kasserine's house?
The situation was that the Germans had created a ruse.
They had come out to attack us.
And what they had done was, and which we couldn't see, was that they were towing anti-tank guns behind their tanks.
In other words, here comes about ten tanks, a lot of dust being stirred up in the desert, a lot of noise.
And you were up on high ground.
I was up on high ground.
And I could see the ten tanks.
Yeah, yeah.
And they're coming out of range.
So they...
